channel.title: Comments on: Adding External Tools to SQL Server
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: David Atkinson
item.dc:creator: David Atkinson
item.description: If you've upgraded to SQL Compare 8.5, this comes with a new add-in, the SSMS Integration Pack, which is a free SSMS extension that integrates SQL Compare and SQL Data Compare into SSMS. Once installed, you can right click on a database and set it as the source or target. If you've got the pro version, any projects you save can be invoked from a submenu. This is a far richer integration compared to using External Tools. In due course, context sensitive shortcuts to all Red Gate tools will be added to this Integration Pack.
item.content:encoded: If you’ve upgraded to SQL Compare 8.5, this comes with a new add-in, the SSMS Integration Pack, which is a free SSMS extension that integrates SQL Compare and SQL Data Compare into SSMS. Once installed, you can right click on a database and set it as the source or target. If you’ve got the pro version, any projects you save can be invoked from a submenu. This is a far richer integration compared to using External Tools. In due course, context sensitive shortcuts to all Red Gate tools will be added to this Integration Pack.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
I used to add Excel, EditPlus and stuff like that back in the 2000 days..now that I have win 7 with the task bar I don’t really need it anymore

Redgate does install right into SSMS and also adds some stuff under external tools…see image below

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.content:encoded:
I’ve been sans-redgate for a while now ( :'( ) but I thought that they installed right into SSMS? Is this only for SSMS 2008, or is it only for some of the tools?

Anyway I’ve never noticed this before, so its a good tip – thanks!
